>a virtual machine? And if virtual machine, which one?
To the best of my knowledge there is no virtual machine on linux that can share the GPU with the host like Windows does, so if you're wanting to game on a VM, you need to have a second graphics card for the host.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

>You can passthru gpu to guest os.
Yes, that's what I said.
But then the host can't use it?
To the best of my knowledge, no VM solution on Linux has GPU virtualisation, so if you want a guest to have a GPU, you need to prevent the host from initialising it (or reboot it), then pass it into the VM for the guest's exclusive use.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1297362
>i5-3570K
With Intel, VT-d is required to do PCI passthrough, and the i5-3570K does not support it.
Even if you were to switch to a CPU that supports it, you also need a motherboard that does not disable it.

Your best bet would be to just use Proton.
https://www.howtogeek.com/738967/how-to-use-steams-proton-to-play-windows-games-on-linux/

Skyrim has a gold rating on ProtonDB:
https://www.protondb.com/app/72850

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1297362
>every couple of updates will cause a problem at boot. Nothing short of reformatting the installation drive works.
If this is something you made a thread about, your disk is still broken and you still need to replace it.
>cpu is an i5-3570K
3xxxK has VT-d (the technology that lets you pass PCI devices to guests) disabled; wiki says you need a 3470, i5-3470S, i5-3475S, i5-3550, i5-3550S, i5-3570, i5-3570S, i5-3570T, i7-3770, i7-3770S or i7-3770T.

>It's called uptalk
No, that's something different.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_rising_terminal

OP asked an "elided question", a question where the actual question clause is elided, to be assumed from context. That's not the same thing as "uptalk", which is a statement that doesn't ask any question, but is spoken as if it did. Key word here is "spoken".

Examples of elided questions:
>Reinstalling the drivers doesn't fix it?
>Reinstalling the drivers doesn't fix it[, so what should I try next]?

>requesting newer fps games recommendations without woke garbage?
>requesting newer fps games recommendations without woke garbage[; which games meet these criteria]?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The proper way is just however you like it. Vanilla is fine, unless you:
want to filter out certain content
often try to source images
often try to look through archives
want to customize UI (use 4chanX and OneeChan for this, although the presets are pretty jarring and I made a ton of settings changes to get it closer to vanilla)
want features like thread watcher, prefetch, show images only, keybinds, custom boards list (including links to generals), etc

I do recommend getting 4chan external sounds since it allows you to add and listen to sound files on boards other than /wsg/ /wsr/ and /gif/, and it doesn't break >>>/global/rules/17 since it's just a link to another site in the filename. How often you'll see it used varies quite a bit between boards.
If you go on flagboards, there are some extensions in >>>/int/extraflag including adding voluntary regional flags and flag listers.
There was recently a thread about 4chan extensions here that had a few other things listed: https://archived.moe/wsr/thread/1292547

posts.sub: Animated movie about a kid losing his sister in a city
posts.com:
I need help finding an animated movie about a kid losing his sister in a big city. I can give you all the details I can remember.

Plot: A little boy and his sister somehow get lost in a big, trashy city. At some point in the movie, the little boy loses his sister in a huge group of people during what looks like rush hour. The sister is swept away in a big, dramatic scene as they both frantically try to find each other.

The people clear and the boy realizes that his sister is nowhere to be scene. The boy then goes on a journey through the city to find his sister and meets a bunch of weird throwaway characters along the way. I remember one of the characters being a rude hotdog vendor smoking a comically large cigar and ashing in the hotdog water.

Eventually, the kid meets a man in a subway station at night. The boy was startled by how gruff and intimidating the man looked, but was calmed when the man turned away from him and laid down in a pile of newspapers. I remember a sappy, sad orchestral song began to play as the kid realized that the man was homeless.

The two of them talked, had a heart-to-heart, yadda yadda yadda, then the kid revealed that he lost his sister in the city and had been looking for her all day. The homeless man then decides to join the boy on his journey to find his sister.

The two leave the subway and a montage of them meeting more strange, rude and "wacky" characters plays. The montage ends with two of them ending up at the entrance of a dark, "spooky" alleyway. The boy is too scared to go inside the alley, but the homeless man tells the boy something like he's been in lots of alleys like this one, so he's got nothing to worry about.

The two of them walk into the alley. The kid looks really nervous as he hesitantly walks behind the homeless man. A scuttling sound echoing through the alley and makes the kid turn around. When he looks back, the homeless man in gone.

>cont

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A voice says something like "up here, child" and the kid looks up to see a giant spider wearing a black suit, a top hat, and what I remember as four monocles on half of his eyes. The spider asks why the kid is scared, then the kid answers that he lost his friend in the alley.

The spider slowly crawls down from the alley wall and says something like "if he was a friend, why would he leave you hear all alone?" I should also note that the spider had a posh English accent and a deep voice.

The spider starts to sing in a kind of slow, opera-esque voice. These are the lyrics I remember, but not sure how accurate they are after so many years.

"Don't you want a friend? A special kind of friend? I will be there 'till the end. I'm just that kind of friend. I may look a bit scary, perhaps a tad too hairy, but a gentleman's cane I carry. But I understand why you're wary."

The giant spider then weaves a piano from his webs and starts playing an upbeat, jazzy sounding song about how he can be the boy's new friend and how lots of people in the city wouldn't make good friends for the boy.

The musical number was full of visual gags, the one I remember the most was the spider playing the drums, the piano and a saxophone or trumpet all at once. The song starts to pick up in speed, the kid is playfully picked up by the spider and set on his back, and they both start dancing.

The song gets faster and I think the lyrics get more revealing about the spider's intentions, then the spider crawls up the alley wall with the kid still on his back. The music crescendos on a shot of the kid's shocked face and then cuts to a shot of the homeless man stuck in a giant web with webbing covering his mouth.

That's right about the time my little brother would start whining about how the movie was scaring him and that he wanted to turn it off. We had a VCR in the living room, so if you watched something, the whole family did, and I only got to watch maybe 30 minutes of it twice.

>cont

posts.name: Anonymous

>>1297281
I think >>1297313 is right. It just has some weird font settings applied to it.
I have that font on my system and I was able to reproduce it (pic related).

Top line is from your pic. The bottom 2 lines are in my terminal using DejaVuSansMono.
The middle line looks almost identical, except when I zoom in your pic seems like it has some minor anti-aliasing. But maybe that's just because the pic was re-sized?

Anyway, the settings I used for the 2nd line are: antialias=false, hintstyle=hintslight, pixelsize=16
For the 3rd line it's the same but I turned on antialiasing.

But if the only reason you like it is because it has that "thin" crisp look, then instead of messing with font settings maybe you should just get a font with embedded bitmaps. If it has bitmaps then it always looks thin and crispy (assuming your system enables bitmap fonts).
Fonts like Terminus, InputMono, or even MSGothic.

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1296718
Japanese animation is the worst in the world; they dominate the industry because they put out so much of it. Think of it like a McDonald's: it's not the place with the best food, but they're everywhere. Western animation is done on 1's or 2's, reserving 3's for some talk scenes and 4's for some extreme cases; western books tell you to never animate on something longer than 4's because it doesn't work, and to stick mostly to 2's. Anime is done on 3's and 4's routinely, and even on 6's on some talk scenes. Play an episode and advance it frame by frame and you'll see it; this is why people need to get used to anime to start enjoying it. This is also why Japanese animation is way cheaper; I don't know the numbers, but I'm gonna make up (grain of salt) that a minute of western animation costs 80k bucks, while a minute of anime about 25k.

Another leg of the tripod is that the LN/Manga/Anime/VN industry has the right sediment for a lot of cheap cartoons to be seasonally produced, and you couldn't do this in another country. To sum it up, it goes something like this:
>people like reading garbage material
>the entry barrier for writing LNs is weak
>a guy publishes a LN (he wouldn't make it as an author in other country)
>people buy the LN (and it takes only a while to consume)
>when the IP has some traction, even Chinese and Koreans investors may fund the anime
>anime is created just to boost sales of the material
>the series is popular = pachinko machines
>people gamble a lot, something between 60-80% of profits of the whole operation come from pachinko, not the actual anime (or BDs)
>Yakuzas do thing with the gold
>the government keeps the loophole open
And don't make me start on mobage built with Chinese capital. The point is that all of this is a small part of an ecosystem of corruption.

>>1296764
>By 1's, 2's, 3's, 4's, and 6's did you mean the length of time between frames?
Yes. 24 FPS doesn't mean 24 drawings. It can be 12 drawings held longer, which would be twos. Eight drawings would be 3's, 24 is ones and so on.
>at 80k a minute a 90 minute film would cost 7.2mil
I don't know the numbers from memory, but the point is that there's a huge gap in the costs. Anyway, I remember that a shitty Yu-Gi-Oh! movie I liked in the 00s costed 20 million to make, so maybe my numbers were actually too cheap.
>>1296765
>You're comparing a film to cheaply made anime series.
This is also a thing that matters. If you're animation for theaters then you do the whole thing on 1's, because some famous animator said that "reality is on ones", so it is accepted that you can't compete in theaters with 2's or worse. This means it's more expensive.

Then you have "limited animation", which is when you have budget and/or time constraints, so it doesn't look as good. Most of the stuff that's not for theaters is limited animation. Now, if you compare Bugs Bunny (an acceptedly bad western cartoon, because they were always on a rush to meet deadlines) with a bad seasonal anime, Buggs still looks better. So the point still stands that low quality western anime > low quality anime.

There can only be 150 threads on a board. When you post in a thread you bump it, making it go to the top. When a new thread gets made, the one at the bottom, which is the one to be bumpped the longest time ago, gets archived or deleted, depending on the board. Archived threads last around 7 or more days but this may vary by board or by the speed of the board, not too sure about this. You can't see all archived posts in the archive section, only recent ones.
You can only bump your own thread once with the same IP. You can post without bumping by typing "sage" in the options field. Moderators can "autosage" threads, making them unable to be bumpped, making them get bumpped off the board faster.
There are plenty of external archives but they don't last forever. You can see the ones still alive here >>1296569 along with the boards they archive.
What brings you here?

1. Found a slightly higher res source:
http://p4room.mda.or.jp/~toppo/20080322.jpg
2. Blew it up 4x with Chainner (4x-AnimeSharp esrgan model).

Then, in Photopea/shop:
3. Masked off the old background.
4. Changed the image size to a 16:9 ratio.
5. Generated a new background (Filter/Render/Clouds + gradient map)
6. Downscaled to 3840x2160 and saved to JPEG.

I am currently researching the earliest mentions of Yume Nikki on the English web, and SA is among the last places I'm unable to query effectively.

4chan discovering the game (Feb. 8th/10th 2008):

Sekhem posting it to newgrounds (Mar. 26th 2008):

Original translation announcement (April 3rd 2008):

Starmen.net thread (April 6th 2008):
